subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quikscript extensions to Shavian (or separate script)

messageBody:
Michael Everson scripsit:

> Please see
> http://www.evertype.com/standards/iso10646/pdf/n4xxx-shavian-additions.pdf
> and please comment as soon as possible. Thank you.

On the question of unification, it would be extremely useful if
you could prepare a short document showing the same passage in
both scripts, similar to your Coptic/Greek/Cyrillic document at
<http://www.evertype.com/standards/cy/coptic.html>. My general feeling
is that the structural correspondences are not enough and that legibility
demands disunification, but seeing is believing.

(From the Read Alphabet list)

> One can always use ZWJ and ZWNJ which are existing characters.

It would certainly do no harm to write a sentence into the proposal
saying that, in accordance with general Unicode rules, ZWNJ blocks a
ligature that the font would otherwise make, and ZWJ forces a ligature
if there is one available, even if the font thinks it shouldn't be used.

Given that, I see no need for intrascript variation selectors. I agree
that using VSs to discriminate between QS and Shavian is to be avoided:
if we need that, we should disunify.

> The fact is that those characters already exist in the Shavian block,
> and if QS is unified with them, it is reasonable to expect them to
> be used.

I don't think that's reasonable at all. Since the letters aren't part
of the QS repertoire, they will not be used, any more than Lithuanian
(say) uses W just because it's part of the Latin script. (Which makes
ethnic Poles in Lithuania very unhappy.)

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
And now here I was, in a country where a right to say how the country should
be governed was restricted to six persons in each thousand of its population.
For the nine hundred and ninety-four to express dissatisfaction with the
regnant system and propose to change it, would have made the whole six
shudder as one man, it would have been so disloyal, so dishonorable, such
putrid black treason. --Mark Twain's Connecticut Yankee
